image.altText: A woman sits on a bench looking unhappy

items.synopsis: One by one, Queensland maternity wards have been closing. A roundtable hopes to fix the problem as the state government announces new funding to encourage midwifery and nursing students to the regions.

title.children: Natasha worries what will happen when she drives two hours to give birth

image.altText: A black and white image of Lorraine Peeters sitting on a chair at a table as a young girl

items.synopsis: Telling her truth helps Lorraine Peeters heal from the trauma of being snatched from her parents as a child and sexually abused while being trained to become a servant for wealthy non-Indigenous families.

title.children: 'I thought it was just a game': Horrific abuse at the hands of matron at Aboriginal girls home

image.altText: a woman wearing a bathing suit standing next to a column

items.synopsis: Two cases, less than six months apart, of women found dead after a delay by NSW Police raises questions about how many other victims of violence are being let down, writes crime reporter Lia Harris.

title.children: A woman was found dead in Sydney after a delayed response to triple-0 call, but she's not the only one

image.altText: A landfill site with a large white "membrane" over the top.

items.synopsis: The closure of north Queensland’s largest landfill has sparked a massive rehabilitation operation that will result in the site being "capped" to look like a natural hill. But what is the true cost of burying the region’s waste?

title.children: What is involved in capping a landfill the size of 20 football fields?

image.altText: Harold Holt kisses his prized catch while holidaying in north Queensland in 1967.

items.synopsis: When anti-Vietnam war protesters rocked Harold Holt's car, his secretary Jan Drury had to be pulled through the passenger-side window. That's just one of her memories of working for the prime minister who went for a swim and never returned.

title.children: Harold Holt's secretary remembers what it was like to work for the prime minister who disappeared

image.altText: A side profile of Mr Chandler-Mather, who is looking off camera.

items.synopsis: The federal government's signature housing policy to establish a $10 billion future fund for social and affordable housing has been stalled for weeks. The Greens are offering a further compromise to guarantee its passage.

title.children: Greens offer compromise to break housing stalemate

image.altText: a league player passes the ball at a match

items.synopsis: NSW Police say they were called to the hotel on South Head Road in Sydney's eastern suburbs just before midnight on Saturday.

title.children: Parramatta Eels star charged with sexual touching after incident at Sydney hotel

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: Australian policymakers should stop using euphemisms to explain how badly people are faring, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: The 'short run' of Australia's economic crisis has begun. How many years before we reach the 'long run'?

image.altText: .Lots of people on a sunny beach.

items.synopsis: The real estate rollercoaster continues as research shows house prices have been rising again throughout Queensland over the past three months.

title.children: Property prices rise in all Queensland regions, Gold and Sunshine coasts lead the way

image.altText: A photo of the iconic archway in Melbourne's Chinatown surrounded by red paper lanterns.

items.synopsis: As Chinatown struggles to return to its pre-COVID golden age, younger generations have been busy creating cultural hubs of their own.

title.children: 'It's not Disneyland': Is Chinatown worth reviving? Or is it just a facade for tourists?

image.altText: An illustration of a destroyed Nokia phone and a close up shot of its IMEI number.

items.synopsis: Political editor Andrew Probyn reveals Australian intelligence's critical role in undoing the men who committed the 2002 Bali bombings — and how a shard from a Nokia phone brought them down.

title.children: How spies used a shard of an exploded Nokia phone to expose the Bali bombers

image.altText: An older man standing near a draw of snail shells.

items.synopsis: John Stanisic has one life mission — to get everyone to love snails and slugs.

title.children: What it takes to be The Snail Whisperer, spreading the Australian snail gospel

image.altText: Nurses Brenna Warren (left) and Rebecca Adam

items.synopsis: Two young women who were born prematurely at the Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital now work as nurses, caring for a new generation of sick newborns.

title.children: Brenna and Rebecca were both born premature. Now they're helping deliver babies in similar situations

image.altText: Li Shangfu salutes before delivering a speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore

items.synopsis: China's Minister of National Defence General Li Shangfu tells Asia's top security summit that his country seeks dialogue over confrontation with the US, despite refusing American demands for military-to-military talks.

title.children: Chinese defence minister says clash with US would be 'unbearable disaster' for the world

image.altText: A black and white photo of Edith Emery as a young woman, her chin resting in her hand

items.synopsis: Edith Emery's life reads like something from a Hollywood movie script — a successful career as a doctor cut short by Hitler's invasion of Austria, a long-distance romance that landed her in a prisoner of war camp, and her final chapter, breaking new ground in Tasmania.

title.children: 'It is as much as one could hope to squeeze into a single life': The remarkable story of Edith Emery

image.altText: A green 'for rent' sign with LEASED stickers stuck on it.

items.synopsis: While Philip Lowe says he wants more people in dwellings, data from house sharing site Flatmates says this is already happening as cost of living and inflation continue to bite Aussies hard.

title.children: Record-breaking numbers are searching for flatmates with older generations increasing the most

image.altText: An old coloured photo of two smiling men in the outback, blue sky, red earth, stand next to ta film camera. Both w

items.synopsis: From gun-slinging stand-offs to scorched testicles, the surviving half of the Leyland Brothers has plenty of stories left to tell.

title.children: Leyland Brothers star Mal plans 'last hurrah' travel documentary adventure across Australia

image.altText: An image of a winnie the pooh storybook talking about run, hide, fight

items.synopsis: Pooh's shift into the public domain sees the loveable teddy appear in some unlikely material.

title.children: Why Winnie the Pooh is teaching Texas children how to navigate school shootings

image.altText: A woman holds her new born baby in a hospital ward

items.synopsis: Over a decade, she went through a tragic stillbirth, 16 rounds of IVF, and hundreds of thousands of dollars. She says clinics behaved more like a business than a health service.

title.children: Treacy had 16 rounds of IVF with no success. It was an acupuncturist's words that led her to a breakthrough

image.altText: Barker with female stall holders and cameraman giving thumbs up as food served from pots.

items.synopsis: After a tumultuous posting marked by natural disasters and disrupted by the COVID pandemic, Indonesia correspondent Anne Barker signs off, reflecting on the big stories, the highs and lows.

title.children: ABC correspondent Anne Barker farewells Indonesia and the world's 'friendliest and most-cheerful' people

image.altText: a composite image of two television characters and a remote control

items.synopsis: From the power struggles within a wealthy family's media empire, to "the opposite of toxic masculinity", what does the popularity of Succession and Ted Lasso say about us — and what are we all going to watch next?

title.children: Why did we fall in love with Ted Lasso and Succession?

image.altText: Australia's Prime Minister drinking beer with a group of people in Vietnam, Hanoi.

items.synopsis: Over beers made from Australian barley, Anthony Albanese toasts Australia's growing trade relationship with Vietnam.

title.children: Albanese visits Hanoi to highlight Australia's growing economic ties to Vietnam

image.altText: trash on mountain

items.synopsis: Food wrappers, tents, plastic and human waste being discarded by climbers staying at the mountain's base camps.

title.children: It's a record Everest climbing season and rubbish is piling up

image.altText: A young Afghan woman wearing a blue high-necked, sleeveless dress poses for a photo.

items.synopsis: Samira was forced to cover her face and body as she fled her homeland. She has now transformed her burqa into a party dress; an act of protest against the Taliban regime and its modesty rules.

title.children: A friend told Samira to burn her burqa to protest the Taliban. She had another idea

image.altText: A teenager with pink hair sits on a park bench, smiling

items.synopsis: American teens are in the grip of a mental health crisis, and one US state says the best way to protect them is to limit their access to social media platforms such as TikTok and Instagram.

title.children: 'Our kids are being harmed': Inside one US state's sweeping new restrictions on teen social media use

image.altText: Man with white beard and glasses sitting in a wheelchair.

items.synopsis: Popular photographer David Blucher was hit by a rider at Canberra's Mount Stromlo, breaking his spine in multiple places. Five months later, he's taking his first steps on a long road to recovery.

title.children: David was photographing mountain bikers when he was struck by a rider. He's now learning to walk again

image.altText: A man in a navy blue suit with a light blue tie sits in front of two flags

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden signs the deal just two days before the Treasury Department warned the US would start running out of money.

title.children: Joe Biden signs bipartisan debt ceiling deal, ending month-long drama that unnerved finance markets

image.altText: People stand next to damaged coaches after two passenger trains collided.

items.synopsis: Rail accidents are far from rare across the globe, with lax regulations, ageing infrastructure and human error all playing their parts in disasters that have killed hundreds of people.

title.children: A timeline of the world's worst rail disasters over the past decade, and what caused them

image.altText: Woman scoops water into a tub with a sea sponge in it

items.synopsis: Antibiotic resistant superbugs are wreaking havoc as experts warn we're in a race against time to find new treatments.

title.children: The world is running out of treatments for deadly infections, but an ancient animal may hold the answer

image.altText: An older man wearing a red jacket and cap stands in front of a vintage plane.

items.synopsis: He lands in a cow paddock to visit country patients, and for fun takes out his vintage plane to lead a regular air show. It's all in a week's work for Dr Cooke, who has no plans to retire any time soon.

title.children: At 81, pilot and doctor David Cooke still flies his own plane to treat patients and loves his job

image.altText: Photo of a blue marron on grass.

items.synopsis: Marron, a large freshwater crayfish endemic to WA's south west, could be soon produced by robotics and artificial intelligence in an effort to boost the availability of the lucrative crayfish to consumers.

title.children: Robots and artificial intelligence could soon be rearing lucrative and highly sought after marron
